 - After obtaining the License to marry the person may go to the persons authorized to solemnize the marriage ceremony. 
 - They may examine the parties on oath, before solemnizing a marriage. 
 - Marriage is solemnized in presence of a person authorized to solemnize marriages and two attending witnesses who shall be at least 16 years of age. 
 - The marriage is considered as solemnized when the parties declare that they take each other as husband and wife in presence of two witnesses and authorized person for solemnizing the marriage. 
 -The person solemnizing a marriage shall prepare and sign three certificates thereof. 
 - Each certificate shall contain the full names before and after marriage and county and state of residences of the parties and the date and place of the marriage. 
 - Each certificate shall also contain the signatures of at least two of the witnesses present at the marriage. 
 - The person solemnizing the marriage shall give each of the parties one such certificate, and shall immediately make a record of such marriage. 
 - The person solemnizing marriage shall file one such certificate with the court administrator of the district court of the county in which the license was issued within five days after the ceremony.

I would certainly argue that, if possible, we should give the benefits of marriage to single people, except for the following: marriage is designed to handle additional needs created by being a member of a family. Because a family has additional needs, they are considered treated equally if their needs are better compensated. I would never say that a family simply deserves more than a single person, I'd say that a family has greater need and therefore needs greater benefits. Furthermore, the benefits of marriage, when one thinks about it, actually do apply to a single person. A single person can claim himself and his children on his taxes. A single person can extend his medical insurance to his children. A single person can get food stamps depending on the size of his family, and a single person has access to his own intellectual property rights. In a marriage, two people agree to become part of the same family, to share those benefits with one another. There simply is no logical way to apply those benefits to a single person.
 
 
Only if they get married. The 14th Amendment doesn't require that for criteria when it comes to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness. Or maybe govt. benefits (whether they be marriage, disability, social security, etc) over and above a life of freedom aren't what the 14th Amendment is about. That's my opinion, anyway.

 
 Well, the 14th Amendment states "equal treatment under the law", and it may indeed be referring to equal freedom and equal life. And that is precisely why it applies to same-sex marriage. Same-sex marriage is very much an issue of freedom, it involves an individual's ability create his own family and have the benefits associated with that family. It is about an individual being allowed to live his own life without having to fear punishment from the government. It is about freedom in the most fundamental sense: it is about freedom from the tyranny of the majority, the freedom to live your life without your neighbors running you out of town, or in this case, without facing less benefits from the government.
 
 I just wish more people would treat others as they would treat themselves, is all, and I think that was the intent behind the 14th Amendment. Too many people insist that others have to be treated differently, that somehow, they just don't qualify for the same treatment. Well I don't buy it.
